cellularAutomata.lattice
Interface Lattice

All Superinterfaces:
java.lang.Iterable<Cell>
All Known Implementing Classes:
BahrLattice, FourNeighborSquareLattice, GlobalSquareLattice, HexagonalLattice, MargolusLattice, MargolusOneDimensionalLattice, MooreRadiusOneDimLattice, MooreRadiusTwoDimLattice, NextNearestOneDimLattice, NextNearestSquareLattice, OneDimensionalLattice, RandomAsymmetricSquareLattice, RandomGaussianLattice, RandomSmallWorldLattice, SquareLattice, StandardOneDimensionalLattice, TriangularLattice, TwelveNeighborTriangularLattice, TwoDimensionalLattice, VonNeumannRadiusLattice
public interface Lattice
extends java.lang.Iterable<Cell>

A lattice is a grid or topology of connected Cells designed with a data structure such as a linked list, array, tree, etc. Typical lattices are one-dimensional lines, two-dimensional square lattices, and two-dimensional hexagonal lattices. The lattice embodies the concept of a "neighborhood", because each cell's neighbors are the ones to which it is connected. In fact, classes that implement this interface may extend other data structures (like a LinkedList or an ArrayList), but the actual lattice topology is controlled by the method getNeighbors(Cell cell).
Note that by contract, all Lattices must have a constructor with the parameters String, Rule, int, and Properties. These are necessary for using reflection properly. There must also be a default constructor (with no parameters). This is enforced nicely by the reflection code, which will warn a developer if they break this rule.

Author:
David Bahr

Field Detail

MAX_RECOMMENDED_NEIGHBORS

static final int MAX_RECOMMENDED_NEIGHBORS
The maximum recommended number of neighbors in a cell's neighborhood. Exceeding this value may cause memory problems on a typical computer.

See Also:
Constant Field Values

WRAP_AROUND_BOUNDARY

static final int WRAP_AROUND_BOUNDARY
The constant specifying a wrap around boundary condition.

See Also:
Constant Field Values

REFLECTION_BOUNDARY

static final int REFLECTION_BOUNDARY
The constant specifying a reflection boundary condition.

See Also:
Constant Field Values
Method Detail

getCells

Cell[] getCells()
Gets all of the cells that make up this lattice. No order is guaranteed but is generally obvious. One-dimensional lattices are generally returned left to right starting with array element 0. Generally, for two-dimensional square lattices, the element array[row][col] is accessed at array[row * width + col].

Returns:
The array of cells that make up this lattice.

getDisplayName

java.lang.String getDisplayName()
A brief one or two-word string describing the rule, appropriate for display in a drop-down list.

NOTE: By contract every lattice class should also have a static variable called DISPLAY_NAME. This is the variable that will be referenced by Rule classes to indicate that they are compatible with this lattice. I don't like this -- should find a better way (perhaps by having the Rule classes reference the lattice class name?).

Returns:
A string no longer than 25 characters.

getFileStorage

FileStorage getFileStorage()
Gets the class that tells the lattice how to store its data in a file.

Returns:
The storage class that tells the lattice how to save to a file.

getHeight

int getHeight()
The height (or number of rows) of the lattice. In one-dimensional lattices, this is always 1.

Returns:
the number of rows in the lattice.

getToolTipDescription

java.lang.String getToolTipDescription()
A tooltip that describes the lattice.

Returns:
The tooltip.

getView

LatticeView getView()
Gets the graphics that tells the lattice how to display itself.

Returns:
The graphics view that tells this Lattice how to display.

getNeighbors

Cell[] getNeighbors(Cell cell)
Returns an array of all cells that are connected to the specified cell, excluding itself. By convention the neighbors should be indexed clockwise starting to the northwest of the cell.

Parameters:
cell - The specified cell.
Returns:
The neighbors of the specified cell (by convention the neighbors should be indexed clockwise starting to the northwest of the cell).

getNumberOfNeighbors

int getNumberOfNeighbors()
Returns the number of neighbors of a cell on the lattice (excluding the cell). If the cells have a varying number of neighbors, then this returns -1, and the user should use getNeighbors(Cell cell) to find the number of neighbors for any particular cell.

Returns:
The number of neighbors for each cell, or -1 if that number is variable.

getWidth

int getWidth()
The width (or number of columns, or length) of the lattice. In one-dimensional lattices, this is the only meaningful dimension.

Returns:
the number of columns in the lattice.

setFileStorage

void setFileStorage(FileStorage storage)
Sets the class that tells the lattice how to store its data in a file. Not necessary to set unless desired because a default is always provided.

Parameters:
storage - The storage class that tells the lattice how to save to a file.

setInitialState

void setInitialState(java.lang.String filePath)
Sets the state of all the cells on the lattice by reading values from a file. The data in the file should be ordered in the same sequence as the Iterator returned by the lattice.

Parameters:
filePath - The path to the file containing the initial state of the automaton. For example, "C:/initial.data".

setView

void setView(LatticeView view)
Sets the graphics that tells the Lattice how to display itself. Unless a non-default is desired, the view does not have to be set by the user (because a default is always used).

Parameters:
view - The graphics view that tells this Lattice how to display.
